title-group.article-title: Surgical Removal of Endometrioma Decreases the NF-kB1 (p50/105) and NF-kB p65 (Rel A) Expression in the Eutopic Endometrium During the Implantation Window

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Obstetric and Gynecology, Inonu University, School of Medicine, Malatya, Turkey
2Department of Physiology, Firat University, School of Medicine, Elazig, Turkey
3Department of Biochemistry, Malatya State Hospital, Malatya, Turkey
4Department of Pathology, Inonu University, School of Medicine, Malatya, Turkey
5Department of Microbiology, Inonu University, School of Medicine, Malatya, Turkey
6Department of Obstetric and Gynecology, Acibadem University, School of Medicine, Istanbul, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Onder Celik, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Inonu University, Turgut Ozal Medical Center, 44069, Malatya, Turkey Email: oncelik@inonu.edu.tr

abstract.p: We aimed to investigate whether the surgical removal of endometrioma alters the nuclear factor-kappa B1 (NF-kB1; p50/105) and NF-kB p65 (Rel A) expression in the eutopic endometrium of infertile women with endometrioma before and after laparoscopic removal of the ovarian endometrioma during the mid-secretory phase. Infertile women with endometrioma (n = 15) were enrolled. Infertile patients with nonendometriotic ovarian cyst (n = 10) and healthy fertile women (n = 10) were recruited as controls. Endometrial samples were obtained before and 3 months after the laparoscopic cystectomy. The NF-kB1 (p50/105) levels were analyzed by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) in the endometrium of all groups before and after laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy during implantation window. Expression of NF-kB1 (p50/105) in eutopic endometrium was significantly higher in infertile women with endometrioma compared to nonendometriotic cyst and fertile controls (P < .05). Laparoscopic cystectomy resulted in a significant decrease in NF-kB1 expression in women with endometrioma. The NF-kB p65 (Rel A) immunoreactivity of eutopic endometrium decreased significantly subsequent to the surgical removal of the endometrioma. In conclusion, increased endometrial NF-kB expression may contribute to endometriosis-associated infertility.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Endometriosis is a common gynecological disease affecting approximately 6% to 10% women of reproductive aged. 1,2 Infertility is one of the common presentations of endometriosis, affecting 30% to 50% of cases. 3 The underlying mechanisms of endometriosis-associated infertility remain elusive. 4 The suggested mechanisms include mechanical factors, defective folliculogenesis, fertilization, and implantation as well as the low oocyte quality. 5 –7 Implantation failure due to the endometrial biochemical defect during the implantation window is one of the possible mechanism underlying endometriosis associated–infertility, particularly in minimal to mild endometriosis in which the mechanical reasons do not explain the infertility. 4,8

The surgical excision of endometrioma in infertile women is controversial. 9 Evidence indicating a decrease in the functional ovarian reserve after the surgical removal of endometrioma has been accumulating. 10,11 Despite the decreased ovarian reserve after the surgery, the pregnancy rate achieved with in vitro fertilization (IVF) was found similar to IVF cycles conducted for tubal factor infertility. 12 The only prospective randomized study evaluating the effect of surgical removal of endometrioma on the IVF outcome and pregnancy rate did not find an augmentation or attenuation in the pregnancy rates. 10 Nevertheless, spontaneous conception is possible in about 50% of subfertile women after the surgical removal of endometrioma, which should not be overlooked. 13

Currently, inflammation and the nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-kB) pathways are the most studied process in the pathogenesis of endometriosis. Its role in the pathophysiology of endometriosis has been demonstrated by previous experimental and clinical studies. 14,15 Further, the NF-kB/p65 expression was found as a predictive marker for the endometriosis recurrence, identifying it as a therapeutic target to prevent recurrence. 16 The invasion enzymes, matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), urokinase-type plasminogen activator (uPA), and tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) in the endometrium have been shown to be positively regulated by NF-kB. 17,18 Thus, the increased NF-kB expression in eutopic endometrium of the endometriosis cases may contribute to the adhesion and invasion of the retrogradely available endometrial tissue to the peritoneum, through activating the invasion enzymes.

The role of NF-kB pathway in the pathophysiology of the endometriosis was further addressed in the endometriosis cases treated with the NF-kB pathway inhibitors. By using 2 different NF-kB inhibitors (pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate and bortezomib), our group has demonstrated diminished cell proliferation and angiogenesis of ectopic lesion and, therefore, a reduction in the endometriotic implant development. 14

The NF-kB pathway was indicated to be active in the normal endometrium of healthy women. 19 –21 However, its expression was found to be altered in the eutopic endometrium of endometriosis. 19,22 Nevertheless, the effect of surgical removal of endometriotic lesion on the NF-kB expression in the eutopic endometrium is unknown.

The NF-kB peptides construct homodimers or heterodimers from 5 subunits: p50/p105 (NF-kB1), p52/p100 (NF-kB2), p65 (RelA), c-Rel, and RelB. Rel-A/NF-kB1 heterodimer is the more commonly found in vivo, and Rel-A is the subunit that most frequently participates in the active NF-kB complex. 23,24 NF-kB1 (p105) and NF-kB2 (p100) are converted into p50 and p52, respectively, which can pass to the nucleus and bind to DNA for activation of gene transcription. However, p65 (Rel A) can readily translocate to the nucleus without any conversion. NF-kB dimers are located in the cell cytoplasm bound to the inhibitor of kappa B protein α (IκBα) that blocks the nuclear translocation of NF-kB. In response to an extracellular signal, NF-kB cascade is activated and IκBα is phosphorylated allowing the release of NF-kB 24 –26 dimers capable of binding to DNA, translocation to the nucleus, and activation of the transcription of several target genes. 27,28

In the present study, we attempted to investigate whether surgical removal of endometrioma alters the NF-kB expression in the eutopic endometrium of infertile women with endometrioma. We evaluated the NF-kB1 (p50/p105) level and NF-kB p65 (Rel A) expression in the eutopic endometrium of infertile patients with endometrioma before and after laparoscopic removal of the ovarian endometrioma during the mid-secretory phase. In addition, to assess the specificity of the results, patients with other benign ovarian cyst that may have clinical, biochemical, and surgical profiles mimicking those of endometrioma should be included as controls. Thus, in the present study, infertile patients with nonendometriotic ovarian cyst and healthy fertile women were recruited as controls.

sec.title: Patients and Study Design
sec.p: We evaluated the NF-kB1 (p105) subunit level and NF-kB p65 (Rel A) subunit expression in the endometrial tissues obtained prior to surgery and respective endometrial tissues after the laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy by stripping method during mid-luteal phase, in 15 infertile women with endometrioma and 10 infertile control cases with benign nonendometriotic ovarian cyst. In addition, endometrial tissues were obtained from 10 healthy fertile women with macroscopically normal pelvic cavities, who underwent laparoscopic tubal ligation or reversal of tubal sterilization before surgery during mid-luteal phase. The study protocol was approved by the institutional Ethical Committee for Research on Human Subjects. Informed written consent forms were obtained from all the participants before recruitment.

All of the infertile women underwent a routine laboratory and radiological examination to diagnose the underlying factors of infertility. The infertile women had normal early follicular follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), estrogen (E2), thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), and prolactine (PRL) levels, and normal midluteal progesterone levels indicating the presence of ovulation, normal 2-semen analysis evaluated at least 3 weeks’ apart and upon 3 to 7 days of abstinence and normal hysterosalpingography (HSG) with bilateral tubal patency and absence of intrauterine mass forming pathology and the only detectable cause of infertility was endometrioma or otherwise unexplained. The fertile women enrolled as the control group had at least 2 children and had no history of infertility or habitual abortion.All the women recruited to the study had regular menstrual cycles, ranging between 21 and 35 days.

The presence of ovarian cyst was diagnosed with a transvaginal ultrasonography (Toshiba Xario, Japan) by using a 5- to 7-MHz transducer. The endometrioma was suspected when a diffuse, regular-margined cyst with a low level internal echo, indicating hemorrhagic cyst, was present for at least 2 cycles, to exclude the nonendometriotic hemorrhagic cyst. The benign nonendometriotic ovarian cysts were diagnosed in the absence of characteristic ultrasonographic appearance for malignancy. The endometrioma and nonendometriotic benign ovarian cyst diagnoses were confirmed with the pathological evaluation of the surgically removed specimen by an experienced gynecologic pathologist. Histologic classification of the specimens was as follows: endometriotic cyst in 15 cases, serous cyst in 4 cases, dermoid cyst in 4 cases, and mucinous cyst in 2 cases.

The surgical technique involved aspiration of the cyst content and removal of the cyst wall by stripping technique. In all the cases, we were able to remove the endometriotic cyst wall from the ovarian tissue, and none of the cases required electrolysis of the cyst wall due to the unsuccessful stripping. We did not electrolyze the superficial peritoneal endometriotic implants accompanying the endometrioma, in any of the cases. The adhesions were removed by hydrodissection and/or scissors. The cases with deep peritoneal endometriosis requiring peritoneal dissection were excluded from the study.

All the participants were required to meet the inclusion criteria: (1) presence of pathological diagnosis of endometrioma or other benign ovarian cyst in women who underwent laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy, (2) no hormonal medication and intrauterine contraception use within the last 6 months before enrollment to the study, and (3) absence of any systemic and/or rheumatologic disease that may lead to an inflammation.

Excluded cases were the ones with (1) malignant ovarian tumor diagnosed with the pathological evaluation of the specimen, (2) previous medication use, (3) bilateral tubal occlusion, (4) previous endometrial pathology such as Asherman syndrome, endometrial polyp, and/or sub-mucous fibroids, (5) diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease, mild peritoneal endometriosis, deep endometriosis, and hydrosalpinx at the time of the study, (6) previous history of abdominal surgery, especially of ovaries, (7) history of habitual abortion, (8) infertility etiology other than endometrioma, (9) out-of-date endometrium on the pathological evaluation of endometrium, and (10) requirement of electrolysis, in addition to stripping, of the endometriotic cyst wall due to densely adherent cyst wall underlying the ovarian tissue.

sec.title: Endometrial Sampling
sec.p: All patients, independent of group, were selected for the present study on the basis of consistent histological findings, menstrual history, and serum progesterone levels. The blood samples were obtained from all participants at the time of endometrial biopsy. Endometrial samples were obtained with a Pipelle catheter (Jiyangsu Medical Materials, China) from all the participants in the mid-luteal phase of the cycle, during the implantation window. The endometrial tissue was divided into 2 sections: one was fixed in 10% formalin and embedded in a paraffin block and the other was washed 3 times with a sterile saline solution to remove blood, and stored in −80°C for future analysis. The ones with endometrioma or nonendometriotic ovarian cyst underwent a second procedure 3 months after the surgical removal of the cyst. The mid-luteal phase was calculated as 7 to 9 days after the ultrasonographic confirmation of ovulation and was confirmed by endometrial histological dating and serum progesterone levels. All menstrual cycles studied in the current study were ovulatory according to mid-luteal serum progesterone >10 ng/mL. Endometrial dating was performed by an independent pathologist experienced in gynecological pathology (N.E.A.). Paraffin-embedded sections of 4 mm was stained with hematoxylin and eosin and periodic acid-Schiff stain. Then these specimens were evaluated according to the histopathological criteria of Noyes et al. 29 An out-of-date biopsy was defined as a lag of ≥3 days between the chronological and the histological day. 30,31

sec.title: NF-kB1 (p105) determination in the supernatant of endometrial tissues by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay
sec.p: In all patients and control participants, endometrial NF-kB1 (p105) subunit concentrations were measured by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), with Alisei fully automated ELISA system (RADIM-SEAC Company, Italy). This immunoassay kit (NF-kB ELISA kit, USCN Life Sci Inc, Wuhan China, Cat No: E1824h) allows for in vitro quantitative determination of human NF-kB1 (p105) concentrations in serum, plasma, urine, tissue homogenates, cell culture supernatants, and other biological fluids. The preparation of tissue homogenates will vary depending upon the tissue type. For this assay, each endometrial sample was rinsed with 1× phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) to remove excess blood and subsequently weighted as wet weight. Then, the clean endometrial samples were homogenized in 1 mL of 1× PBS and stored overnight at a temperature ≤ −20°C. After 2 freeze–thaw cycles were performed to break the cell membranes, the homogenates were centrifuged for 5 minutes at 4000 rpm. The supernatant was stored at −80°C to avoid loss of bioactivity and contamination. The detection range of kit was 0.312 to 20 ng/mL. The intra-(within day) and inter-assay (between days) coefficients of variation for endometrial NF-kB1 (p105) were <10% and <12%, respectively. The results of NF-kB1 (p105) concentrations detected by immunoassay kit were divided by the weights of endometrial tissue. The results were presented as ng/mg tissue.

sec.title: Immunohistochemical labeling for NF-kappa B/p65 (Rel A) Ab-1
sec.p: Four micrometer paraffin sections on poly-l-lysine–coated slides were used after drying in an oven for 1 hour at 60°C. The sections were de-waxed in xylene, rehydrated in ethanol, and incubated for 10 minutes in 3% hydrogen peroxide to block endogenous peroxidase. After washing in PBS, the sections were incubated for 8 minutes in ultra V block. The immunoreaction was performed for 60 minutes with ready-to-use NF-kappa B/p65 (Rel A) Ab-1 antibody (NeoMarkers, Labvision Corp, California). After washing in PBS, the slides were incubated with horseradish peroxidase (HRP) kit. For negative control, the endometrial tissue was incubated with nonimmune rabbit serum in place of the primary antibody. Finally, the preparations were developed in 3-Amino-9-Ethylcarbazole (AEC) chromogen counterstained with hematoxylin and mounted with aqueous mount. Third-trimester human placenta served as the positive control.

To evaluate the immunhistochemical NF-kB p65 (Rel A) expression in the endometrium, the H-score method was used. 32 This immunohistochemical semiquantitative method consists of the percentages of positively stained cells multiplied by a weighted intensity of staining: H-score = ΣPi (i + 1), where Pi is the percentage of stained cells in each intensity category (0%-100%), and i is the intensity indicating weak (i = 1), moderate (i = 2), or strong (i = 3) staining. 32,33

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: The normality distribution of data was performed using Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, and all variables were skewed normally. The continuous variables were analyzed by analysis of variance (ANOVA) test with post hoc Tukey procedure and Mann-Whitney U test. The categorical data were analyzed by the Pearson chi-square test. A P value <.05 was considered significant. The results are expressed as mean and standard deviation (SD). The data were analyzed using the Statistical Package for Social Sciences software 19.0 for Windows package software (SPSS, Inc, Chicago, Illinois).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The demographic characteristics of each group are presented in Table 1. Each group of patients had normal body mass index. The mean size of endometrioma was also similar to the mean size of nonendometriotic cysts (P = .44). In the endometrioma group, the cysts were bilateral in 10 women and unilateral in 5 women.

fn.p: Abbreviations: NS, nonsignificant; SD, standard deviation.
a Values are presented as mean and SD unless otherwise stated.

sec.title: Endometrial NF-kB1 (p105) Levels in the Infertile Women With Endometrioma, Nonendometriotic Ovarian Cyst and Fertile Women
sec.p: The endometrial NF-kB1 (p105) levels were analyzed using ELISA method. The mean NF-kB1 (p105) level was significantly higher in the eutopic endometrium of women with endometrioma before the removal of cyst compared to cases with nonendometriotic cyst and fertile cases (P < .0001 and P < .0001, respectively). The mean endometrial NF-kB1 (p105) levels were similar in the endometrioma cases with unilateral and bilateral endometrioma, before the surgical removal of the cysts (P = .85). Surgical removal of the endometrioma decreased the mean endometrial NF-kB1 (p105) levels to those with nonendometriotic cyst before and after the cystectomy and in fertile women, in both unilateral and bilateral endometrioma cases (Table 2, Figure 1). The mean endometrial NF-kB1 (p105) levels were similar in the nonendometriotic cyst group before the surgery and the fertile group (P = .96). The removal of cyst did not change the endometrial NF-kB1 (p105) levels in the nonendometriotic cyst group (Table 2).

caption.p: The nuclear factor-kappa B1 (NF-kB1; p50/105) levels in mid-luteal endometrium from infertile women with endometrioma prior to surgery, those after surgical removal, nonendometriotic ovarian cysts prior to surgery, those after surgical removal, and in fertile women.
Comparisons of NF-kB1 Concentrations (p50/105) and H-Score of Immunohistochemical NF Kappa B/65 (RelA) Expression Among the Groups

tr.th: H-Score of NF kappa B/65 (RelA) expression

fn.p: Abbreviations: NF-kB, nuclear factor-kappa B; SD, standard deviation; ANOVA, analysis of variance; NS, nonsignificant; NA, not applicable.

a Data are presented as mean and SD. Comparisons between each outcome group with fertile group (ANOVA test with post hoc Tukey procedure for continuous variables). P1 represent for comparison of NF-kB1 (p50/105) between the groups; P2 represent for comparison of H-Score of immunohistochemical NF kappa B/65 (RelA) expression between the groups.

sec.title: Immunohistochemical Expression of NF Kappa B/p65 (Rel A) Ab-1 in the Endometrium Samples From Infertile Women With Endometrioma, Fertile Group, and Infertile Women With Nonendometriotic Ovarian Cysts
sec.p: Immunohistochemical analysis confirmed the ELISA findings in each group. The increased NF-kB p65 (Rel A) immunoreactivity was predominantly localized to the cytoplasm of luminal and glandular epithelial cells in the endometrioma group (Figure 2). After surgical removal of endometrioma, the mean H-score of endometrial NF-kB p65 (Rel A) expression significantly decreased to a level similar to that of the fertile group and the preoperative and postoperative levels of nonendometriotic cyst group (P = .32, Table 2). Furthermore, there was no statistically significant difference in the mean H-score of endometrial NF-kB p65 (Rel A) expression between the nonendometriotic cyst group before and after the cystectomy (P = .99) and the fertile group (P=0.096).

caption.p: Immunohistochemical staining of nuclear factor (NF) kappa B/65 (Rel A) in endometrium from women with endometrioma before (A) and after (B) surgery; nonendometriotic cyst before (C) and after (D) surgery. Inlet (A) shows negative control (proliferative endometrium). Intense glandular NF kappa B/65 staining in the endometrium from women with endometrioma before surgery (A; arrows) significantly decreased after surgery (B; arrow). The intensity of glandular NF kappa B/65 staining in the endometrium from woman with nonendometriotic cyst before surgery (C; arrow) was similar after surgery (D; arrow). (E) An endometrial sample from fertile control and (F) positive control (third-trimester placenta showing circumferential cytoplasmic positivity [arrow] in the trophoblastic cells in the small villus [V]).

sec.title: Comments
sec.p: The current study demonstrates that the NF-kB1 (p105) levels and NF-kB p65 (Rel A) expression increase in the mid-secretory eutopic endometrium of infertile cases with endometrioma, during the implantation window. NF-kB1 (p105) levels and NF-kB p65 (Rel A) expression were, at a similar rate, high in both unilateral and bilateral endometrioma cases. One of the mechanisms responsible for infertility in our study group may be the elevated NF-kB expression in the eutopic endometrium.

The NF-kB pathway is one of the important pathways regulating immunity and inflammation. 26 Menstruation and the implantation are mainly inflammatory processes of the endometrium. Unfortunately, only limited data are available regarding the role of the NF-kB pathway in the endometrium. The NF-kB expression was found elevated during the menstrual endometrium. 20 However, its role in the endometrial receptivity is conflicting. Progesterone was found to inhibit the NF-kB pathway through increasing the IκBα (NF-kB inhibitor) messenger RNA (mRNA) expression. 20 The low NF-kB expression was detected in the secretory endometrium compared to menstrual endometrium. 21 Nevertheless, an NF-kB pathway intermediate, IKKβ expression, was observed high in the secretory endometrium. 20 Proinflammatory signals like interleukin (IL)-1, tumor necrosis factor- α (TNF-α), and prostaglandins activate IKKβ, which in turn activates the NF-kB by releasing it from the inhibition of IκBα. 20 In a previous study, administration of the NF-kB inhibitors decreased the production of endometrial receptivity markers, IL-6 and LIF. 19 Thereby, NF-kB pathway playing a role in the endometrial receptivity.

A very recent study comparing the NF-kB expression on the proliferative, secretory, and menstrual endometrium in healthy women and women with endometriosis found the physiologic pattern of NF-kB expression altered in cases with endometriosis. 21 The authors also observed that NF-kB expression was increased in secretory as well as the proliferative endometrium compared to the menstrual endometrium in women with endometriosis, while it was increased only in the proliferative endometrium of healthy women. The findings of Ponce et al 34 were opposing to that of our study and González-Ramos et al’s. 21 That study did not find a difference in the cytoplasmic and nuclear Rel-A levels as well as the Rel-A DNA binding in the mid-secretory eutopic endometrium of cases with endometriosis compared to fertile women without endometriosis. Nevertheless, that study conducted by Ponce et al 34 consisted of a heterogenous group of endometriosis cases with an American Fertility Society (AFS) score ranging between 3 and 118. Considering the fact that only 4 or 5 women were analyzed in each proliferative, early-, mid- and late-secretory endometrium groups, early stage endometriosis cases may be analyzed in some of the groups and late stage endometriosis in the other groups. Therefore, the discrepancy between the results of our study and the results of Ponce et al’s study may be due to a grouping bias.

The NF-kB has been shown to interact with the progesterone receptor and inhibit its action. 35 Several studies have demonstrated an attenuated or deregulated progesterone response at a molecular level in endometrium from women with endometriosis. 36,37 Therefore, the loss of physiologic pattern of NF-kB expression could be responsible for the progesterone resistance in the endometriosis. Nevertheless, this may also impair the endometrial receptivity.

Progesterone stimulus is essential for the decidualization of the endometrial stromal cells and the establishment of the endometrial receptivity. 38 Progesterone influences the expression of Homeobox protein A-10 (HOXA-10) and HOXA-11 in the mid- and late-secretory endometrium. 39,40 The great body of evidence suggests that HOX genes are essential for endometrial growth, differentiation, and receptivity by mediating some functions of the sex steroids during each reproductive cycle. 41 Nevertheless, HOX gene expression was found low in the eutopic endometrium of cases with endometriosis. One of the mechanisms underlying the decreased HOX gene expression can be progesterone resistance present in the endometriosis. Another mechanism proposed was the epigenetic changes and hypermethylation of the HOXA-10 gene, resulting in decreased expression. 42 –44 Evidence suggests that the chronic inflammation can lead to epigenetic changes and cancer formation. 45,46 Hence, chronic inflammation mediated by increased NF-kB expression in endometriosis may lead to HOXA-10 hypermethylation and interfere with endometrial receptivity.

Another possible mechanism can be through the interference with the prolactin gene expression in the endometrium. In a study, transcription factor binding sites for HOXA10 and HOXA11, Forkhead box protein O1 (FOXO1) as well as NF-kB were found on the 200 kb of a Eutherian-specific transposable element (MER20) dPRL enhancer region of the PRL gene, activating its expression. 47 Prolactin is upregulated during decidualization and its proper regulation is essential for implantation and pregnancy. 48,49 Hence, nonphysiologic pattern of NF-kB expression may interfere with the PRL gene expression and may alter the implantation in women with endometriosis.

The current study demonstrates that after surgical removal of endometrioma in both unilateral and bilateral endometrioma, the NF-kB1 levels and NF-kB p65 expression have decreased and reached to a level similar to fertile women without any pelvic pathology. The NF-kB1 levels and NF-kB p65 expression in the eutopic endometrium of cases with nonendometriotic benign ovarian cyst were also similar to fertile women without any pelvic pathology, and the endometrial NF-kB1 levels and NF-kB p65 expression did not vary after the surgical removal of the cyst. In view of these findings, it may be assumed that the elevated NF-kB expression in the eutopic endometrium is due to the chronic inflammatory condition in the endometrioma rather than a mass effect of the cyst itself.

Evidence supports that a physiologic amount of inflammation is necessary for endometrial receptivity and early pregnancy implantation. However, pathologic inflammation was found to interfere with the endometrial receptivity and early pregnancy implantation. Hydrosalpinx is a typical inflammatory condition associated with a 50% reduction in implantation rates in IVF cycles. 50,51 The other inflammatory conditions with decreased implantation rates are polycystic ovarian syndrome, uterine polyps, and fibroids as well as the endometriosis. The expression of well-characterized endometrial receptivity genes HOXA-10 and HOXA-11 fails during the implantation window in cases with hydrosalpinx, polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), uterine fibroids, and endometriosis. 40,52,53 Furthermore, the expressions of various other mediators of endometrial receptivity, which are also mediated by HOX genes, such as pinopodes, αvß3 integrin, and insulin growth factor binding protein 1 (IGFBP-1), are found to be decreased in endometriosis. 33,54,55 Since the paucity of assessment of endometrial receptivity markers before and after the removal of endometrioma in the current study, we do not know the effect of decreased NF-kB levels on the endometrial receptivity markers. However, salpingectomy upregulated the HOXA-10 expression to normal levels 4 months after the surgery. 56 Thus, laparoscopic removal of endometrioma, similar to salpingectomy in hydrosalpinx, may improve the endometrium by decreasing the NF-kB levels during the implantation window. In the current study, we evaluated the endometrial NF-kB levels 3 months after the surgery. The interval necessary for the resolution of the inflammation after the treatment depends on the degree of inflammatory reaction. Nevertheless the 3 months’ interval resulted in a significant decrease in the endometrial NF-kB levels after the endometrioma removal. Therefore, this study suggests that a minimum time interval of 3 months would be enough for the evaluation of endometrium after the endometrioma surgery.

A limitation of the current study is that we did not evaluate the DNA binding or the inhibitor of kappa B protein (IkB) phosphorylation of NF-kB in the eutopic endometrium of cases with and without endometrioma. Therefore, increased NF-kB expression does not mean increased NF-kB activity, and we are not able to comment on whether the elevated NF-kB level and expression reflected altered gene transcription.

In conclusion, the current study demonstrates that the NF-kB1 levels and NF-kB p65 expression increase in the eutopic endometrium of infertile women with endometrioma during the implantation window. Laparoscopic removal of the endometrioma by stripping technique decreases the NF-kB1 levels and NF-kB p65 expression to a similar level of fertile women. The elevated NF-kB1 levels and NF-kB p65 expression in the eutopic endometrium are almost similar in women with either unilateral or bilateral endometrioma and decrease with similar rates of fertile NF-kB levels with removal of the endometrioma in both cases. It may be concluded that surgical removal of endometrioma, therefore, can be beneficial in infertile women with no other infertility etiology and may improve the eutopic endometrium.

ack.p: We appreciate Dr Barıs Otlu who allowed us to use his Molecular Microbiology Laboratory of Inonu University.
